title: Stdio::Pipe not working on Windows Server 2012
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
use std::process::{Command, Stdio};
use std::io::{Read, Write};
use std::path::Prefix::Verbatim;

const POWERSHELL_PROMPT_FUNCTION: &str = "function prompt { $res=$?; [Console]::Error.WriteLine('PS8jalda4sdaAlKjasd49saada4s' + $res + '>'); 'PS8jalda4sdaAlKjasd49saada4s' + $res + '>' + [Environment]::NewLine }";

fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");

    let command = Command::new("powershell.exe")
        .arg("-nologo")
        .arg("-NoExit")
        .arg("-Command")
        .arg(POWERSHELL_PROMPT_FUNCTION)
        .stdin(Stdio::piped())
        .stderr(Stdio::piped())
        .stdout(Stdio::piped())
        .spawn().unwrap();


    let mut res= String::new();
    command.stdin.unwrap().write("echo hallo".as_bytes());
    command.stdout.unwrap().read_to_string(&mut res).unwrap();
    println!("res {:?}", res);

}

```

I expected to see this happen:

The Output of the started Powershell should not be visible in the Shell that I do 'cargo run'.
Under Windows Server 2019 and Windows 10 this works as expected.

Instead, this happened: 
The spawned powershell starts in the foreground, and the ouput shows up in my original shell.

Output:
```
Hello, world!
PS8jalda4sdaAlKjasd49saada4sTrue>
exit (input my me)
res ""

```
